dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR KENNER
dialogues.text: It’s nice to have you back, Martha.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Thanks Doctor Kenner, I spent like, the last fifteen days in bed crying, out of bed crying, back in bed, so, here I am, here is me. Kenner nods and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR KENNER
dialogues.text: And, how would you say you’re feeling now?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I guess I just feel...I don’t know. I'd want to say I feel betrayed, but is that, is that cliche?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR KENNER
dialogues.text: No, it’s not cliche if it’s what you feel.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I just don’t want to hide behind pre- established ideas, I mean, I’ve been cheated on before.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR KENNER
dialogues.text: I know, Daniel.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: That's right, but this is different. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR KENNER
dialogues.text: Do you feel Robert did something different? You were with him for just under a year.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: It’s not that he did something different, I just...It was like he had another life. One woman, I could handle, it’d be fucked up, but I could handle it. (slowly sits up as she talks) But I mean...I have no idea, it’s scary, but I have no idea how many women he was sleeping with. And I mean, they weren't, I’ve seen them. They weren’t like, better than me.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR KENNER
dialogues.text: Did you want them to be?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Well no, I just...I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR KENNER
dialogues.text: Do you feel like it’s your fault?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: My fault?

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR KENNER
dialogues.text: Think about it. Martha sits thinking.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (shaking her head) No, NO, okay, no, I don’t feel that way. Why should I, I gave him everything, I trusted him, and then to go through his phone and find text messages about having anal sex in a hot tub? That’s what eleven months earned me? My fucking fault? Fuck that. Doctor Kenner looks uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But you know, maybe it is. It’s my fault for ever thinking this guy, this sycophantic, smarmy pretentious piece of self-involved dogshit could ever-

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR KENNER
dialogues.text: I think you’re being unfair, here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (beat) What? Unfair to him? What? This awful unbelievable fucking asshole who acts like he wants to marry me and then every second we're apart is balls deep in some harem of washed out sluts-—

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR KENNER
dialogues.text: (adjusting her glasses) Sluts is a very strong term. I think you need to be a little understanding; Robbie is a very high pressure, intense individual and... Doctor Kenner trails off as she realizes that Martha is staring at her very, very intensely. DOCTOR KENNER (CONT’D) I... Martha leaps to her feet, grabbing a vase off the table n to the couch and hurling it at the wall next to Doctor Kenner.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (screaming)

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: The opening credits are juxtaposed with two different processes: the factory production of bullets and prescrip antidepressants/antipsychotics. COME BACK IN ON...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a lot on the edge of the city, barely lit. The burni car sits in the center, and two other men stand a couple dozen feet away, by another car. VON Cartigan, late 30s, well dressed and handsome, with a spry, boyish look about him and cowboy boots, stands coun money in a briefcase on the trunk of the car. JOHNNY HOWL, stocky, 40s, with an eerie jack-o-lantern fa stands watching the car burn. Von looks at the money and tips his head to the side, thinking. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: You think that was too much?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY HOWL
dialogues.text: It’s never too much, Von.

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: Seemed a mite excessive, with his kid in the car.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY HOWL
dialogues.text: He shouldn’t have brought his kid.

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: So it’s acceptable losses?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY HOWL
dialogues.text: (beat) Yeah. Von closes the briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: You’re a sick fuck, Johnny Howl.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY HOWL
dialogues.text: (beat) Yeah. Von pops the trunk, and starts to put in the briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY HOWL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey Von. Von looks up, and Johnny nods at a badly burnt man, who’s crawling away from the car. Von laughs, and closes the trunk, then heads over to the crawling man.

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: Hello down there, Buddy. Rough night? The man lets out a hissing sound. Von stomps repeatedly on the back of the man’s knees with harsh cracking sounds. Von stops, and takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: VON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t crawl, Buddy, it’s undignified. (beat, then takes a moment, and smiles at Johnny) Johnny, help me put him back in the car. The man lets out a horrified groan as Johnny Howl approac smiling. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THE BEEPING OF AN ALARM CLOCK.
dialogues.text: INT. MARTHA’S APARTMENT - BEDROOM Martha’s alarm is going off, but her bed is empty. The ro is a mess, clothes everywhere, dirty glasses strewn here there. There is a diorama of the primeval world, old and tattered, spread across the wall, and a single wooden sculpture of a pterodactyl hanging from the ceiling. ELAINE Schiff, early 30s, tall and wiry, peeks in.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Martha, are you... Elaine comes into the room, looking around. There’s a lou thump from inside the closed closet.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (muffled) Shut up! Elaine looks concerned. INT. MARTHA’S APARTMENT —- HALLWAY - LATER Elaine walks along, leading TATIANA Ruiz, early 30s, Cuba stout but pretty.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: It’s as bad as I’ve seen her, Tati.

dialogues.speaker: TATIANA
dialogues.text: Where is she now? INT. MARTHA’S APARTMENT - BEDROOM - CONTINUOUS Elaine and Tatiana come in.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: She’s drunk in the closet again. There’s a crashing sound from the closet. Tatiana sighs, goes over to the door.

dialogues.speaker: TATIANA
dialogues.text: Martha? Are you okay in there?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Amflegblamersh! JIHHHH! Tatiana looks to Elaine, who makes a “yikes” face. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TATIANA
dialogues.text: I want to come in. Can I come in?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (inhuman demonic screaming) No0oocc00000000000000! Tatiana opens the door, revealing Martha laying in a pile fallen jackets, shirts and dresses. The closet is a wreck

dialogues.speaker: TATIANA
dialogues.text: (concerned) Oh Martha...What is this?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I’ve only been drinking for three...Days, but I haven’t missed work. I have missed work. Tatiana kneels down next to Martha.

dialogues.speaker: TATIANA
dialogues.text: Come on, honey, let’s-

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I think you don’t know anything about this situation, you don’t know anything about the world...I’m gonna PUNCH YOU IN THE FACE...yourself...You better check yourself... Tatiana helps Martha up, near to against her will.

dialogues.speaker: TATIANA
dialogues.text: Elaine give me a hand.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (muttering) Checkyoself into a hospital...emergency room...after I mega...

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: I’m not touching her, she’s all...sticky.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (muttering) -..mega-punch... Martha collapses onto the floor.  INT. MARTHA’S APARTMENT —- BATHROOM - SHORTLY THEREAFTER Martha’s bathroom is strictly whites and purples. She sta staring at herself in the mirror, squinting her eyes very hard, then staring again. She’s rocking in place a little

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (quietly) Goddamn it. Martha brushes back her hair, and then stops, holding it back. She brushes the other side back, and then holds it She cocks her head, looking at herself. She opens a drawer, revealing a pair of electric clippers

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. RIGHT, 30, handsome with wavy, messy brown hair, walk the street. He has a lighter-than-air, poppy, bubbly air about him, as though he just walked out of a musical come He is constantly looking around, smiling blissfully and blankly at everything. Right stops in front of a tall building, checks the addre grins and goes in. We stay there on the lobby, and then shoot up the side of building around twenty stories, and stop at a window into nice apartment. A well dressed woman answers the door; it’s Right. He smiles, and they exchange words as he goes in. She looks very serious. Mr. Right looks hesitant. He seems to repeatedly, incredulous but friendly, ask the same questi The woman fervently nods. Mr. Right shrugs, pulls a red foam clown nose out of his pocket, puts it on, draws out a pistol and shoots her in heart. She falls down against the wall, startled. Right takes a contemplative bite of out a Rice-Krispie tr EXT. MARTHA’S APARTMENT - BEDROOM Elaine is cleaning, while Tatianna talks on the phone. It getting dark outside. Martha abruptly bursts out of the bathroom; we see Elaine and Tatianna react sharply. Martha has cut off a good 85% of her hair. Martha tosses Elaine a pair of car keys.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Heads up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The keys smack Elaine in the face, and she gasps, holding eye.

dialogues.speaker: TATIANA
dialogues.text: Martha, jesus christ.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I thought she would catch it with her mad skills. (beat, leans back) But, I guess she just kinda sucks. We’re going out, right? We’re going out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is a little crowded; Elaine and Tatianna are at bar, they look nervous. Martha comes up, holding drinks; of the cups is empty, which she hands to Tatiana.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Hellloooo laaaadddiieeesss.

dialogues.speaker: TATIANA
dialogues.text: (to her empty cup) What the hell is this?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Well, it was supposed to be a sex on the beach but I drank it, so now it’s just a cup.

dialogues.speaker: TATIANA
dialogues.text: Jesus christ, Martha.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (excited, looking around) Oh, is he here? Martha separates from her friends, and goes off to dance. Out on the dance floor, Martha appears to be having a goo time dancing alone, when SOME GUY, mid-20s, reasonably attractive, approaches.

dialogues.speaker: SOME GUY
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (smiles) Hey!

dialogues.speaker: SOME GUY
dialogues.text: Who are you here with? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: My friends.

dialogues.speaker: SOME GUY
dialogues.text: (laughs) No boyfriend? Martha abruptly stops dancing.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: My boyfriend was killed by velociraptors.

dialogues.speaker: SOME GUY
dialogues.text: What? (beat) Was that a joke? Martha looks very sad. SOME GUY (CONT’D) No, come on, it’s joke. Martha has started to cry. SOME GUY (CONT’D) Don’t do that...It was a joke...Don’t... Some Guy awkwardly moves back into the crowd, and Martha snickers, wiping her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha, Tatianna and Elaine walk up the road.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: That was incredible!

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: How was that incredible?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: It’s been forever since I’ve just been, you know, out like that, not trying to get laid.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: You’re lucky we love you, Martie.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Yes I am! Hey, hoes before bros, right? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Martha offers out a fist.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right? Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: TATIANA
dialogues.text: You’re out of control, girl. You are out of control. A car blurs by and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the near empty parking lot of a city zoo, a single expensive towncar sits alone, lights off, with heavily ti windows. A dozen feet or so away from the car stands SHOT STEVE Gage, late 20s, with a sly, wiry look about him, al like a human coyote. He lights a cigarette. Directly outside the car is BRUCE Cooper, 30s, black, lea and well dressed. He's trying to calm down CHARLIE Cartig who looks incensed.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Dead!? What the fuck do you mean, dead?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: If you'd just get in the car, Mr. Cartigan, we could-

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Fuck you, I’m not getting in the car, this ain’t a fuckin’ meet. If you want to wake a man up at three in the fuck AM you best have some kind of explanation, better than “Minkin is dead,” I don’t care who the fuck my nephews think they are- The driver’s side window rolls down, revealing RICHARD Cartigan, 42, bearing a distinct resemblance his brother and clearly trying to look dignified.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Charlie, get in the car.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What’re we doing here, Richard-

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Get in the car. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay. The back door opens, and Richard gets in. Richard looks t Bruce, who rolls his eyes. Richard smiles, and rolls up t window.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE CAR
dialogues.text: Charlie gets in the back, looking around. Von sits in the passenger's side, and Johnny Howl sits in the back, playi with a Rubik’s cube. They all look nervous. There’s a charged silence. CHARLIE (CONT’D) What is this? (referencing Johnny Howl) What’s this ghoul doing here?

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: We have a problem.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Yeah, so I’ve fuckin’ heard, but it can’t wait till morning-

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: It might be my fault.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Are the Picolos involved in this? I thought they were all dead-

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: No, but it’s very, very serious.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: So serious that we all might be in danger. Everyone’s quiet for a moment. Johnny Howl grins.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What did you do, Von? Von's silent.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (disgusted) You fuckin’ kids, playing at being gangsters-— (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny tak: 12.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Von took someone out, one of Yatsuda’s guys, and it looks like Yatsuda isn’t taking it well.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why the fuck would you start shit with Bobby Yatsuda, are you fuckin’ suicidal?

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: He shitted us out on cash, Uncle Charlie. The dumbfuck shitted us out, big time, we couldn’t just let it stand.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Fuckin’ drugs? This was over fuckin’ drugs again?

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: Well-

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter what it was over.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: No, I suppose it wouldn’t to you, would it. You know, Rich, I woulda seen this dumb shit coming from Von, I really would have. But you? Is this where you’re going too, with this garbage-

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter, Charlie, what matters is that we’re targets now. Von says he’s got some guys who can take care of this for us.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: “Take care” of Bobby Yatsuda? Are you both out of your fucking minds?

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: Show him the list, Johnny. es out a rumpled list of phone numbers, handing it over to Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: It’s a list I made up; those are the numbers of the best trigger guys in the city. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: What, we’re going to get some Slovakian douchebag to take down Bobby Yatsuda-

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: No, no, these aren’t thugs, man. These are the real deal, hitmen.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hitmen? Shit, you guys are...Man, I ain't heard someone talking about hiring a real gun since the seventies.

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: Some of the numbers might not work, but if you can get a guy, then-

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Why me?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: The way Von figures it we’ve got a better chance of getting quality if we use you. No one gives a shit about Dickie and Von Cartigan, but Charles Cartigan, the Hammer, you’re a name. Charlie stares at the list.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: You kids are really for real about this. Von looks nervously at Richard.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: The way I see it, Von hasn't left us much of a choice. Charlie stares at the list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s a petshop in a strip mall. There’s a loud shattering sound. CUT TO: A FURIOUS CAT’S SNARLING FACE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the kennel in the back of the store, a single longhair cat, deranged with fear and anger, has escaped from its carrier and knocked over a glass-fronted cabinet. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: It sits in the center of the room, roaring furiously at Martha and Elaine, now dressed in work clothes, who stand facing it.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Isn’t it supposed to find a corner?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: No, he wants to throwdown.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Cats aren’t supposed to throw down! The cat screams.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: He wants to throw down pound for pound like we were clowns that tried to mess around.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Gimme the net. Elaine gets a short-handled net from off a counter, and tosses it to Martha.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: He‘’ll just run.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: He wants to take me on, you want to take me on, come on ese I’1l cut you up! The cat screams with the fury of hell.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh you talk a big game now but not so big when I make you my bitch. (to Elaine) Go around back of him, startle him towards me. Elaine nods, and goes around back of the cat. Martha and cat lock eyes, and then Elaine jumps towards the cat.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Boo! The cat turns and pounces onto her face. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (rushing to help her) Oh shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both women are sitting, covered in little bloody scratche and liquid cat diarrhea. Elaine is smoking a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (continuing her thought) It just exploded.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Like a burst fire hydrant of cat shit, that was unreal.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Do you think that’s a defense mechanism, or-

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I think he was just that scared of us. We're really hardcore.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: How bad is the one on my elbow?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Oof. Bad. See this is why I’m never gonna be a lesbian. Elaine looks at her, confused.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pussy is crazy dangerous. Elaine sits in silence, and then starts laughing.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: You are, I think, actually retarded-

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (standing up) Yeah yeah, I'ma hit the drugstore. Martha heads off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: It isn’t lunch yet!

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (calling back) I know.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: You're covered in blood and cat shit!

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (from further yet away) I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha is waiting in line at the pharmacy, staring at a b “The Bahamas: Rediscover Love! Rediscover Life!” banner u on the wall. Mr. Right sits off to the side in the waiting area. He’s staring intently at his hands. People are kind of shying away from Martha, due to the smell and appearance, causin Right to notice her as she approaches the counter.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: Name please?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Martha McKay.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: Meflem?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Mick-AY.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. The pharmacist goes back to the medications. Martha glanc around, noticing Mr. Right STARING at her. Martha picks u her birth control, and turns, heading away from the pharm She glances back to Right, but he’s gone. She looks down, a little glum, and walks directly into a display of cough-drops; boxes scatter and fall in all directions. We see Martha’s POV, slow motion; as one of the boxes fal we see a dotted line draw out, predicting where it’s head Martha begins to reach out towards it. FREEZE. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Suddenly, every single falling box grows a prediction lin UNFREEZE. Martha catches the single box, but no other boxes fall. S looks up to see Mr. Right, holding all of the boxes. He looks earnestly cautious, as though he may have just viol a boundary.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (quietly) How did you do that.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (nods at the single box she holds) How did you do that? Martha stands silently for a moment. Right casually takes the box from her, and replaces them all on the display. S notices Right staring at her again.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: It was a cat.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: A cat, did this.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Did what? Martha blinks, staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You want a lifesaver? Martha looks at him quizzically.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (reflective) I like lifesavers very much.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (beat) Do those work? Right just looks bewildered. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “Ooh, I'm nice lifesaver guy, you’re clumsy and vulnerable, look how handsome I am.” Do you have a secret stock of lifesaver based jokes? Do you buy them in bulk? Right stares at her emptily.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (blankly, as though by rote) I like lifesavers very much. Martha tries to move past him, and he blocks her way. Mar takes a step back, reevaluating the situation.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that creepy? Sometimes I don’t know when I’m being creepy. Right moves aside.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I get too forward, and then-

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Who...are you?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Should I give you a fake name or my real one? Martha stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Fake name.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Hubert Cumberbund.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: “Hubert Cumberbund.”

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: My friends call me Huey. Martha stares at him for a moment more and then laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I can’t believe I’m talking to you, Huey.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (genuinely confused) But...it’s happening. (MORE) g (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) Do you wanna go get coffee? Like, hang out and stuff?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (laughs again) You are just...Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (chipper ) I need my prescriptions so I don’t feel angry all the time.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I don’t think any one’s ever used that as pick-up line before.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (looks around, then whispers confidentially) Is it working?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (laughing and vehemently shaking her head) No, no it isn’t.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, it’s the best I’ve got. I’m not very suave.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Oh really?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: No, not really, actually I am very suave.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (beat) Okay, explain why I should “hang out” with you in two words.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (beat) “Or else?” Martha stares at him, and then Right winks at her, and sh starts laughing. Right notices the circular box Martha is holding.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, are those birth control? (beat) Awesome.  20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha and Right sit together on the ground against the s of the restaurant. Both of them have kids’ meals in color cardboard containers, which they are opening.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: What’d you get, what’d you get?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Hold on, hold on... (takes out her toy) Green Parrot. What’d you get?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Dog with Spot. Dog With Spot beats Green Parrot.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: What? No way. Green Parrot can fly. (beat) Plus, he had this really bad childhood, so now he carries a knife with him everywhere. Right laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: His parole officer tries to send him in the right direction, but Green Parrot is just too... (laughs) What about Dog with Spot?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (shakes his head sadly) He had so much promise, but dropped out of college, lives with his girlfriend, she supports him...Not a pretty story, really.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Is this story indicative of you, or-

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: No, nah. So you were telling me about the museum?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Right, worked there for two years, and now, back to the petstore.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Wait, back to Petacular with Elaine? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Thus the cat shit, yes.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: But I thought you said you were going to end up managing the Egyptian thing-

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Right, I was, but I’m...People have trouble working with me.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah? You're a troublemaker?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (grins) No, I just...I have some “restraint issues.” I’m kind of impulsive.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I find that really attractive.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Oh, you wouldn't if you knew me.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I’m impulsive too.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (beat) What do you do, exactly?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I sell cars, and I kill people.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Oh, you split the time?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (laughing) Seventy-thirty, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine stands alone behind the counter. She looks around, and then looks at the clock on the wall.

dialogues.speaker: SIDE PARK
dialogues.text: Martha and Right walk along the edge of an urban lake, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Dragons? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Yeah dragons. Humans put names on everything to make them safe, but when you come down to it, a whale is just a sea monster, right? I mean, what’s a dinosaur other than a dragon? As Martha talks, an errant frisbee nearly hits Right; seemingly without even looking, he catches it and throws back. Martha lau

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: People see things and they put labels on them, and it takes the...The whatever, the wonder out. It allows people to just glance at stuff instead of really looking.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: People prefer that, I think. Most people live in little contained worlds; they like a T-Rex better as a big bunch of bones than as something that actually lived.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe. That’s why I got into paleontology in the first place, because I wanted to show the past to people in a new way. I thought by now I’d be working in the Smithsonian, but I can’t...

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Impulsive, right.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Right. (beat) We haven’t really, yknow, talked about you much.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Well that’s a shame, because I’m very, very interesting. ghs, but then they’re interrupted by a CHONGA, early twenties, latina, sexy, who stands with her friends around a picnic table in the park.

dialogues.speaker: CHONGA
dialogues.text: Hey, hey wifey! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Yeah, can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: CHONGA
dialogues.text: Ain’t you know Robbie Hewitt?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (slowly) Yeah... The chonga says something to her friends, and they all la

dialogues.speaker: CHONGA
dialogues.text: Well you tell him he need to call me back, because- The chonga notices that Martha is charging at her, scream and looking crazy.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: CARTIGAN’S BROWNSTONE

dialogues.speaker: APARTMENT
dialogues.text: INT. CHARLIE CARTIGAN’S PLACE - LIVING ROOM Charlie Cartigan sits alone in his living room, staring a the crumpled list Von gave him. He sighs, and dials one o the numbers. It’s disconnected. He tries another, and it’ again disconnected. CUT TO: SAME, LATER. Charlie’s on the phone with Von. We intercut back and for to Von, who’s in an ARCADE playing a stand-up video game while Johnny Howl sits on a pinball machine behind him.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The numbers don’t work.

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: How many did you try?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: I tried six, they’re all disconnected-

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: Well I told you some of them wouldn’t work, Uncle Charlie, you’ve just gotta go till you get one. These are the best around, they don’t stay in the same place for long, right? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Right, I guess, but I’m supposed to go through every number here?

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: Well what was I supposed to do, call and then hang up if they answer? That’s a good way to get myself shot- Von dies in the game, causing Johnny Howl to chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: VON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Agh, goddamnit!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: (concerned) You okay?

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: Look, I’m fine, Charlie, and I’m sorry about the numbers, but just please, do your best, okay? Von hangs up as a big, bulky ARCADE EMPLOYEE comes up to Johnny Howl.

dialogues.speaker: ARCADE EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: Hey, man, please don’t sit on the machines. Johnny Howl looks to Von.

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m done anyway. Johnny Howl abruptly spins around behind the bulky guy, a instantly slits his throat with a straight razor. Blood splatters onto the pinball machine, and the man fal behind it. It all happened so fast, no one in the arcade even noticed. Von chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: VON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY HOWL
dialogues.text: No, I wanted to-

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: Let's go. BACK TO: CHARLIE CARTIGAN’S APARTMENT —- LATER (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Charlie hangs up his phone, crossing off another number, frustrated. He sighs, and dials again. CUT TO: RIVERSIDE WALKWAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Right and Martha are posted out down by the water, relaxing. Night has fallen, and the park is lit by street lamps. Martha is even further mussed. Right’s cell phone rings, and he flips it open.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Anyone interesting?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Probably not. Right flips the cell phone closed again.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve never, I don’t think I’ve ever seen a woman throw punches like that before.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, she escaped, so mission failure, I think.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: She was one of the girls sleeping with...

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I don’t get that. I mean, if you’re ina relationship, you’ve got to be locked down. I don’t even know how someone starts into something, why they would start into something if they didn’t know right then and there they wanted to commit. Martha smiles, and looks down. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See, I think my problem has always been that if you want someone, really want them, you’ve got to know immediately and stick by it. Recently, I don’t want to throw myself out there for anyone to pick up. I’ve just been trying to take life more seriously, you know? Martha looks up, and gasps, then laughs; Mr. Right has pu the red foam clown nose. He takes it off, pocketing it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: The corniest guy alive.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: It's possible.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: So, are you against casual sex, then?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I don’t think I’ve ever had sex that wasn’t casual; I mean, I usually do it naked, so what’s more casual than that. Martha laughs.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was dating a girl, for a while, and we were having formal sex; I had to wear a tuxedo. It was really sweaty- Martha keeps laughing.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I dated a girl where we had, like, semi-formal sex; I had to wear a button up. Condom. Martha grabs Right and kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: JUMP CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MARTHA’S APARTMENT - HALLWAY - SOON AFTER Right and Martha crash into the apartment hallway, still making out. Elaine peeks her head out from her room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Oh, uh, hello. Martha ducks off into her room.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (muttering, embarrassed) Oh, uh, my hair...

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (to Elaine) Hello Elaine!

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Have we...met?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (cheery) No! Elaine stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m in love with Martha. You and me are going to be friends! Elaine quietly goes back into her room, shutting the door She opens the door again for a moment, staring at him. Mr Right sort of shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE CHANNELS.
dialogues.text: INT. MARTHA’S APARTMENT —- BEDROOM The lights are off. Mr. Right lays on the bed, shoes and socks off, flipping through the channels. He stops, stari at the diorama on the wall. Martha comes out of the bathroom in a towel, with a towel around her hair. She notices Right staring at the diorama and looks at him questioningly.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (by way of clarification) Dragons. Martha has to stop a frighteningly big smile, and then co her face, slightly embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (smiles) It’s cool. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She and Mr. Right stare at each other for a moment, and t she crawls out onto the bed, and lays down next to him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: If we don’t... Mr. Right just looks at her, and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean, will you still stay? Mr. Right smiles, and then nods. She kisses him gently on the lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the street on the roof of a building, Agent Bart HOPPER, 54, with a widows peak, looks down at Martha’s wi through binoculars. Next to him, Agent WALLY Kinokis, 30, gruff looking, pops open a pack of nicotine gum. Both of them, from their clothes to their posture, read as FBI.

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: They fucking?

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: (beat) Nope.

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: You think he’s gonna kill her?

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but you must have a theory-

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: Does chewing that gum help you at all?

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: (beat) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: Then chew the damn gum. Wally shrugs.  29. INT. MARTHA’S APARTMENT —- BEDROOM —- MORNING Martha lays asleep, alone, in bed; her towel has come mos unwrapped, and we can see her bare back and a little bit her butt. She blinks, awaking and realizing she’s alone, then notices a note on her bed. Drawn on it is a simple, childlike image of Martha fighti cat like a lion tamer, with stiff block letters under it. HAVE TO GO TO WORK. I WILL SEE YOU TONIGHT.” She stares a it for a moment, and then slowly allows herself to smile. INT. CAR DEALERSHIP - RIGHT’S OFFICE Right sits at his desk, talking on the phone, looking out window. The nameplate reads “Clark Speck.” There’s a wind up toy on his desk, wandering along.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: No, I see the convertibles. (listens) I see them, I do, but you have to understand, when I say we can’t move convertibles I mean we can’t move convertibles, I’m not going to make up a sales problem, here. Someone walks by, and he covers the phone, calling out to them.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mitch, hey Mitch! The man stops and looks into the office.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m in love! Mitch shrugs, and keeps walking. Right goes back to the phone.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, I’ll get back to you about this on Tuesday, okay? Okay. Right. Okay. Mr. Right hangs up, and sits for a moment, and then takes his cell phone. It reads “ONE NEW VOICEMAIL.” Right, making the strange, dead face, presses send.  30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Elaine and Martha are loading crates of Kitty Litter up o the shelves.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: an ou ire someone Oo oO 1s? Can't you hi to do this?

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: I did, I hired you.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Yeah, but someone to do it for us, while we watched. Elaine just shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Why did Busta sleep in my room last night?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: It was weird, he wouldn’t come in while... (laughs) I just realized I don’t know his real name.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Who, Mr. Right?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Mm, I like that.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: You slept with him and you don’t even know his-

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I slept with him, I didn’t screw him-

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: You don’t even know his name? Martha’s quiet.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And Busta wouldn’t come in...You know, they say animals can sense evil. Martha glares at her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: He’s not “evil.” Ooh, actually, what if he is? I hope he is. Martha lifts a big crate of cat litter up onto the shelf.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When I was little I always had this fantasy of dating Lex Luthor.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Lex Luthor was a genius. Your guy...he’s like, like some kinda hot Rain Man or something. Martha laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I think I’m in love with him. Is that stupid?

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: ..-Yes. Martha rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Don’t roll your eyes!

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: You’re in love with a man you met yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I don’t know, I think so. Elaine’s quiet for a moment, then sighs.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: That’s how my mother and father met. Love at first sight.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Don’t start smiling, you’re not them. Martha keeps smiling.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’re not them! And this guy is weird, okay? And he makes you weird. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I’m already weird.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: When a dude cheats on you, you’re supposed to reject men, not just go gaga over the next one you bump into ina drugstore.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Hey, like you said. “Mr. Right.” Elaine sighs dramatically, and then laughs.

dialogues.speaker: A PISTOL.
dialogues.text: INT. MR. RIGHT’S STORAGE CONTAINER - CONTINUOUS Mr. Right sits in a storage container, wearing only an undershirt and underwear. On a crate in front of him he’s laid out a dozen different types of pistols, and he’s loo over them, thinking. His face is dead and emotionless. We pan to reveal that the wall behind him is covered with guns; it is not, however, simply an armory. There is only one gun of each type; one sniper rifle, one combat rifle, submachine gun, etc. What we’re looking at isn’t an arsen it’s a toolbox. His cell phone rings, and he takes it out. It reads “Mart Monster.”

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Monster?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right and Martha are both slightly dressed up. They’re waiting for their food.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: You want to call me “Monster?”

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: It’s a nickname, you know, monster, marth, marthster, that sort of-

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: No, I get it, I just...I like it. Monster. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Monsta.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Better than Agatha.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I think Agatha is an excellent middle name, Martha, I don’t know why you don’t like it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Martha Agatha, I sound like I was born an old lady.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I like old ladies. The way they smell, the way their skin feels. You know, when I kiss you, I just, I feel like I’m making out with my grandma, and it just turns me on so much I can’t even stand it-

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (laughing) Oh my god, stop it, stop it. Right smiles.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: You’re so...hot. Martha blinks.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I want to come around the table and sit next to you, can I do that?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I want to come around-

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: No, I...I think you should definitely do that. Break the face to face code of table dining. Right laughs, and moves his chair around the table so he next to her. The food arrives, and the confused waiter pu the plates down in front of them. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Right looks up, and catches Martha staring at him. She coughs, and looks down at her food. INT. RIGHT’S APARTMENT - LATER Right's apartment is primarily decorated in greens, taste very organized, minimalist. Martha sits on his couch, looking around. Right is in the kitchen, making hot chocolate.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (calling to him) What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (spraying whipcream onto the hot chocolate) My name?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Yeah, I was, I was enjoying the whole not knowing thing, but I mean, I feel like it’s done now. Right comes over to her, and hands her her mug of hot chocolate.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: The truth is, I don’t really like my name. I kind of hate it. Even hearing it makes me kind of angry, I...I have a lot of anger about a lot of things. I’m kind of messed up in a lot of ways. I've been completely honest with you about everything, it’s only two days in so I know that’s not a big accomplishment or something, but I just...I really don’t like my name. I don’t want to tell you it, because I don’t want to hear you say it. Martha stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: How did you do that thing in the store.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: What thing?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: You moved...the way you move sometimes. Like you already know how things are going to- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (a little self-conscious) Oh, right. That.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Is this a thing?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: No, it’s... Martha waits. Right seems to think for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ON A TABLE
dialogues.text: It's a little later, and Martha and Right now stand next his table. Martha looks a little apprehensive.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (straightening out the knives) I’ve always found it easier to show, rather than just try to explain-

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Is this going to get, like, scary?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: No scarier than usual, I don’t think.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: There aren’t usually knives.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: You never play with knives?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: A quick montage of Martha playing with knives in various locations; frightening Tatianna, twirling them clumsily i front of a mirror, running one up her arm and getting the shivers, violently and theatrically slicing an onion “HIY HIYA!” and finally 80s home video footage of Little Marth running holding a bunch of knives yelling “I GOT KNIFES F FINGAHZ!" with her frantic father chasing after her, stop for a moment to turn to the camera and shout “Christy put camera down!”

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO
dialogues.text: MARTHA’S (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: First time for everything. Martha smiles nervously.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: It's slightly later; Right and Martha are nearer to the center of the room. Right stands behind their bodies pres together, limbs moving slowly, synchronized, just an easy gradual dance. As they move, Right talks.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ever since I was a little boy, I’ve had an idea. It’s a theory. (he leans back, forcing her to lay back on him, and runs her own hands up her body) Keep up.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (trying to keep her balance) I’m trying.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Everything we see, like physical things, it’s all just islands. And under it, carrying it, is this sweeping current. He brings their right hands up in front of Martha’s face, moves it fluidly back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And if you pay attention, you can start to feel it. Here, you see how your hand moves with mine? You can feel it. You can feel it through me. Do you feel it? Martha’s quiet as they move, trying to figure out if this just foreplay, or if that strange sensation she’s feeling counts at what Right is talking about. He subtly grabs a knife off the table with his left hand, and then continue moving, bringing the knife dangerously close to her throa (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (a little afraid, staring at the knife) I...uh...

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: It's okay, just concentrate on the knife. (beat) Now if we can feel the current, we can feel other things in the current, other moving things, people...watch the knife...And we can feel how the current will move them, and we can see where they’1l go. It’s all in the movement, see, it pushes itself; it’s easier to move with it than against it. Martha’s gaze moves from knife to Right’s arm, and, very faintly, we see the dotted trace lines from his shoulder, elbow, his wrist and the tip of the knife. Right, staring at Martha, watching her face, abruptly drops the knife, brin his and her other hands directly under it. Martha yelps and jumps away, and Right easily catches kni

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Jesus christ!

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Why the fuck would you-

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I thought you would catch it.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Catch it, jesus-

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (suddenly concerned and apologetic) Did it not work? Did you not see where it was going to go? Martha’s quiet for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: You could’ve cut me- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Then why didn’t you catch it?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I can't catch a knife-

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Yes you can.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: No I can't.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Yes you can. Martha shakes her head, as though waking up from a dream. -she heads

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I don’t even know your name, and you just, attacked me-

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I didn’t attack you, I just-

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (straightening herself) Look, um, I had a really nice night, but I have to-

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I could tell you can feel it. You don’t know how yet, but I can keep showing you, I-

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: No, really- (picking up her purse) That’s great, but I need to leave, now, and I- towards the door-

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -think it would be better off if we just took a day or-

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: But you felt it!

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter what I-

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Martha. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Martha turns, just in time to see Right toss the knife at her. Time stops for a second, Martha’s eyes wide, staring at t knife as it spins towards her. Martha’s hand shoots up and plucks the knife out of the a holding it by the blade. There’s absolute stillness, with Right realizing he just went way over the line to prove h point. Luckily, Martha is sprinting past that line as well. She lets out short, deep, throaty “hur-hur-hur” laugh, starin the knife.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (whispering) That’s so gnarly- Mr. Right tosses another knife at her, and Martha catches almost without looking.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, no more, okay, it...I get it.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Gimme one of those back. Martha throws a knife to Right, which he easily catches, spins, and whips back at her, along with a second knife. throws the first knife at Right, and then catches both ne knives, and then has to catch the first knife as Right to it back at her. She stares at the three knives in her hands as Right approaches.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: It's like a...Like a pulse?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (thinking) Like everything is on strings, or...God, it’s like trying to describe doing acid, I can’t... (thinks) It's like everything is moving together at once, and I just-

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I was worried. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I’ve never tried to explain it to anyone before, and I thought it would sound stupid, or that-

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: No, no it just... (beat) You've never talked about this to anyone?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Why me?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (beat) Because I wanted you to know. I needed you to know. You have this grace about you, I can’t even describe it, and I knew...I just knew you’d understand.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Is that how you knew I’d catch the knife?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I didn’t know you’d catch the knife. Martha stares at him, not questioning, just listening.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I believed you could catch the knife. I wanted you to catch the knife. But there was no way I could know. You’re the one that did it. You’re the one who knew. Martha looks down, thinking very hard.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, are you mad, or- Martha looks back up to him, and wipes her eye. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: I’m not mad. (beat) I want you. I really, really do. Right makes a wide-eyed face of surprise.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I think that’s...that’s doable.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: No, I mean, like, immediately. They stand there staring at each other. INT. RIGHT’S APARTMENT - BEDROOM - MORNING Martha and Right lay in bed together, naked. Mr. Right is asleep. Martha is awake, staring straight ahead, a blank, happy smile on her face.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Martha stands in Mr. Right’s bathroom, naked, looking at prescription medication bottles. None of them have labels She gives them a cursory examination, and then looks at h toothbrush, his deodorant, and then his shaving razor. She is quietly, serenely happy.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Martha is in the shower, washing her hair, when Mr. Right gets in, also naked, and immediately starts kissing her, pushing her up against the wall of the shower.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. MR. RIGHT’S CAR - SHORTLY THEREAFTER Mr. Right is driving, with Martha next to him. They’re bo quiet and happy. They come to a red light, and Mr. Right notices the car’s clock; 9:43 AM.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Ooh, damnit.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I’m a dumb ass, I forgot something. Do you mind if we make a stop? It’1l only take a second. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: No, uh, whatever, it’s alllll gooood. (beat, looks out the window) That... Last night was the first time anyone’s called me hot.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: What? No way.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: No, it’s true. I mean, guys say shit like that like right before or during sex, and I always assumed it was just because I looked better in dim lighting- (Right laughs) ) But I’ve never had anyone just say it like that.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I hope that’s not why you love me. (beat) Do you love me? Right smiles. Martha smiles. The light turns green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right pulls up, and parks. Out on a park bench sits Charl Cartigan, but otherwise, the park is entirely empty. Char fidgets nervously, waiting, holding a plastic bag.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: There’s my guy. I'’11 be right back, okay?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Okay. Mr. Right leans over and kisses her. He then gets out, an heads off towards Charlie. Martha sits in silence for a moment, and then turns on the radio; it’s a pop love song She changes, it, country. Changes it again, and comes ont heavy, bass-thumping, hardcore rap. Martha smiles and calmly lip-syncs the words. OVER BY THE BENCH... Charlie stands up as Right approaches.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Are you the guy? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I’m a guy, sure. They both sit down.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How’d you get my number?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Doesn’t matter.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (beat) No, I guess it doesn’t. So what do you need?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hah. What do I “need.” We see, from Martha’s vantage point, Charlie hand Right envelope from the plastic bag.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everything’s in there.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (cordial) You're sure about this.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Sure about what?

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: You’re sure that you want me to kill whoever it is that’s identified in this envelope. Charlie blinks, shocked.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, I don’t...What’re you- 43. an Right sighs and impatiently tears open the envelope. Insi is picture of BOBBY YATSUDA, a vicious looking Asian Amer man in his 50s, along with some documents.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Him?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, don’t do that- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: This Bobby Yatusda, you want me to kill Bobby Yatsuda?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Well, jesus, I don’t... (looks around, baffled) Uh...Is this a-

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: It's not a trick. It’s not a game. You want me to kill this man.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLIE
dialogues.text: -..Yes? Mr. Right gives a somewhat sad smile.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Okay. Martha watches from the car as Right and Charlie stand up shake hands. Mr. Right then puts on the clown nose. Charlie looks confused. Mr. Right suddenly drops a gun out of his sleeve and shoo Charlie through the side of the face. Martha gasps, her e wide. Right catches Charlie as he falls forward, and we c see him saying “Oh, shit, sorry.” Right apologetically gives the horrified Martha a “one second” finger, shrugs and mouths the word “sorry.” Charlie tries to draw his gun, and Right abruptly shoots in the forehead, then turns and briskly starts walking ba to the car. Charlie’s body falls dead. Martha sits frozen in the car. Mr. Right walks to the car and gets in, giving her a quick smile.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I told you it’d only take a second. (beat) Is something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (quietly, staring down) Take me home.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I...Well, I was going to do that an ay.. yway (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) Are you mad because I shot that guy? Martha is silent, and then raises her eyes to make contac with his.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Martha, how I felt about that guy has nothing to do with how I feel about you. Martha drops eye contact. Right sighs, and puts the car i gear. They drive out of the parking lot, and we hold on the emp park. We pan to reveal Johnny Howl, sitting in a innocuou sedan. He stares at the body of Charlie Cartigan in silen his reaction is unreadable. He sighs, blowing out smoke and then tosses out his cigarette, and starts the car. EXT. MARTHA’S APARTMENT - STREET LEVEL Right pulls up, letting Martha out. She immediately goes the stairs, but he gets out.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: Martha, wait. Martha stops on the stoop, and turns around.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t...I’m not a bad person. I don’t think before I act sometimes, but...I love you, and I’m not a bad person. Martha slowly nods, and goes inside. Right sighs, and kic the car, and then gets in and drives away. Across the street, in an alley, Johnny Howl watches the building. INT. MARTHA’S APARTMENT - HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS Martha comes in, closes the door, leans and then slumps against it, staring straight ahead. We see her view of th apartment, empty and hostile. Busta, her cat, meows, approaching. She slowly pets the cat, staring blankly at anything and everything. She walks over to the window, and closes the shades.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE STREET.
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Johnny smiles, looking at Martha in her window. INT. RICHARD’S OFFICE It's a plush office, in an office building. Johnny Howl stands across a desk from Richard, who’s seated, on the e of either tears or an explosive outburst. Von leans again the wall; he looks shocked and horrified. Bruce stands behind Richard, listening.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I don’t...understand.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY HOWL
dialogues.text: The guy just walked up and shot him, like that. Nothing to it. I don’t see what the big fuss is, we just-

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Von you shut him up or I swear to god-

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: Howl, shut your mouth. Johnny makes a big show of being quiet.

dialogues.speaker: VON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s Yatsuda, it must be.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: How did he know?

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: He’s Bobby fucking Yatsuda-

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: And I’m Richard Fucking Cartigan, who the fuck are you, Von? This is on your head; you’ve been trouble ever since you came back to us from the Picolos. Von looks hurt.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: Why would Yatsuda hire a contractor?

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: I mean, we haven’t felt any backlash from Yatsuda himself, why would he hire some random gun to take out- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: Who gives a shit, Bruce? We go get this guy, eye for an eye, yeah? Bruce looks annoyed, and Richard sits, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY HOWL
dialogues.text: I got two addresses. (puts them out on the table) That’s his job, that’s his girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: BRUCE
dialogues.text: (confused) His girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (emotional) Get some guys. Take him out. Tonight. Do it. Von and Johnny briefly make eye contact, and then Johnny nods. INT. MARTHA’S APARTMENT - BATHROOM - LATER Martha sits on her toilet, not moving. There’s a knock at the door, which she ignores. Another knock, harder. OUT IN THE HALLWAY. Elaine hurries up, eating yogurt, and answers the door. A Hopper and Agent Kinokis stand waiting. Hopper raises his badge.

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: I’m Agent Hopper, this is Wally-

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: (hurriedly) -Agent Kinokis-

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: Yeah, we’re here to talk to Martha McKay.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: (frozen in place) Is there a problem, or...

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: Well, her new boyfriend’s killed eighty nine people, so if you consider that a problem, yeah. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Elaine drops her yogurt spoon on the floor. CUT TO: SHOTGUN STEVE’S BEWILDERED FACE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Johnny Howl is handing out guns and ammunition to three g SAW, who holds a massive Madsen machine gun, UZI, who hol an Uzi, and Shotgun Steve, who’s been given an ancient Pa shotgun. ZEKE, late 20s, with spiked hair, a collared shi and a better than you attitude, stands by in the backgrou

dialogues.speaker: SHOTGUN STEVE
dialogues.text: What the fuck am I supposed to do with this?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY HOWL
dialogues.text: Shoot him.

dialogues.speaker: SHOTGUN STEVE
dialogues.text: This thing is from like world war fucking one, you said this guy was some kinda super sonic psycho killer and I’m going to go out fucking duck hunting-

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY HOWL
dialogues.text: Look, we’re hitting him at his straight job, at closing. The guy has no idea what's coming. Walk up on him and shoot him in the face, how much of a fuckin’ retard would you have to be to screw that up?

dialogues.speaker: SHOTGUN STEVE
dialogues.text: S'just-

dialogues.speaker: ZEKE
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up, Steve.

dialogues.speaker: SHOTGUN STEVE
dialogues.text: (ignoring him) And why isn’t Zeke coming?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY HOWL
dialogues.text: I need Zeke here with me. Just shut your mouth, do your job, or I’1l cut your fucking cheeks out, yeah? Steve is reluctantly quiet.  49. INT. MARTHA’S APARTMENT —- LIVING ROOM Martha sits motionless at a eaves-table; Elaine is pacing behind her, looking shaky. Hopper is seated across from h and Wally stands behind him; Hopper’s open briefcase sits a chair next to him.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: He’s...he’s not a bad person. Hopper laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: You don’t even know what he is, who he is-

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: (interrupting her) His name is Francis Minch. He’s a psychopath. Hopper spreads some photos out on the table, mugshots, ne photographs of assassinations.

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He was formerly one of the world’s most notorious professional killers. He had been ever since he was a teenager, just a kind of meat-grinder of a man. But then, about a year ago, he had a nervous breakdown and quit.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: (cutting off Hopper) He’s a psychopath, not a sociopath. The guy has emotions. He has guilt. They’re just operating on a real low level, and his “feelings” just finally caught up with him. (beat, a look from Hopper) That’s the theory, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (quietly) Then what was today?

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: If he’s not a hitman anymore, why did he kill that man in the park? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a beat, Hopper smiles an odd smile.

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: After the breakdown, Minch developed a kind of moral code. He’s still notorious. People still try to hire him. But now, he kills them.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: He kills the people who hire him?

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: Because “murder” is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: That’s insane.

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: So is Francis Minch. Martha and Elaine are silent.

dialogues.speaker: ELAINE
dialogues.text: Just how dangerous is he?

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: Oh, there’s no kind of chart. Minch isn’t some kind of superhero, he’s as human as you and me, he’s just...He’s just frighteningly efficient. He dances in, kills everyone, and dances out. (to himself, ponderous) It's kind of beautiful, really. 50. A long beat. Martha and Hopper have made eye contact, and there’s an odd kind of understanding. Elaine and Wally lo distinctly non-plussed.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: (quietly) So what now.

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: (standing) The man you witnessed him killing today was heavily involved in organized crime. We should expect retribution. We're arranging a safe-house for you; until then, we’re putting this apartment under protection. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WALLY
dialogues.text: If he makes any attempt to contact you, you talk to us immediately, right? Martha just sits there, still shell-shocked.

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: Right. She’s got it. Martha stares at nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Right is locking up, and waving goodbye to coworkers they leave. He begins to walk alone through the lot, and then takes out his cell phone, dialing Martha.

dialogues.speaker: AT HER PHONE.
dialogues.text: It reads MR.RIGHT. She lets it ring, near tears.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO
dialogues.text: Right sighs, pocketing his phone, and then stops. We see way he views the world; everything in the lot seems to va piece by piece, leaving the Shotgun Steve, Uzi and SAW he across the lot towards him, moving in a void. Everything comes back, and Right stares at them, not movi Uzi opens fire, blasting the car Right stands next to, an keeps shooting. The windows shatter and the car’s alarm g off. Right, either knowing that he’s beyond Uzi’s ability to a with any kind of accuracy or simply not caring, continues look vacantly at the trio of men; “Oh?”. He puts on the clown nose. Steve shoves down Uzi’s gun by the barrel, burning his ha

dialogues.speaker: SHOTGUN STEVE
dialogues.text: Agh, shit, STOP FUCKING SHOOTING! Right crouches down, and slowly, carefully starts squat- walking through the row of cars. He looks agitated, but n scared or nervous. Out in the circle, Shotgun Steve, Uzi and SAW look around very quietly. The car alarm screams in the night. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SAW
dialogues.text: Where’d he go?

dialogues.speaker: SHOTGUN STEVE
dialogues.text: (quietly) God fucking damn it, why did you start shooting-

dialogues.speaker: UZI
dialogues.text: Shut up, pussy, I didn’t see you doing jack shit and- Shotgun Steve abruptly raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: SHOTGUN STEVE
dialogues.text: Shh-sh-shh. The car alarm keeps going off into the night. SAW sees something move, and turns, raising the machine gun, unloa BRAKABRAKABRAKABRAKA into the side of three sedans; all o their alarms go off, beginning the overture of a crazed, dysphoric symphony. Shotgun slaps SAW on the back of the head. SHOTGUN STEVE (CONT’D) What the fuck, Jimmy?

dialogues.speaker: SAW
dialogues.text: He mighta been back there. Maybe I already got him. The trio stands there waiting, and then there’s a thump, a car alarm starts going off behind them. The three turn, and SAW raises his gun, but Shotgun slaps it down. They stand there listening to the car alarms. There’s a thump from the other side of circle, and anothe alarm joins the chorus. Then another, and another.

dialogues.speaker: SHOTGUN STEVE
dialogues.text: Ah man; all right, let’s get out of here. There are two more thumps, and two more sirens start as t men slowly begin to back out of the maze of cars.

dialogues.speaker: ALONG THE ASPHALT UNDER THE CARS.
dialogues.text: BOOM! A car on the other side of the lot EXPLODES into flames. All three men turn, looking at the explosion, not noticing that Mr. Right now stands between SAW and UZI. Mr. Right leans over Saw’s shoulder, talking into his ear (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (gleeful whisper) I'm gonna shoot you. It is here for the first time that we see Mr. Right ina combat situation. When he moves, it is in strictly sweeps glides and snaps; it could be compared to the dancing of Kelly and Fred Astaire, in that everything looks effortle and smooth. The effect is visually beautiful, blindingly fast, and absolutely lethal. Saw turns around, firing the massive machine gun at rando whereupon Mr. Right grape-vines his arm and quickly shoot him the in the side of the head, then gracefully turns, s Uzi’s gun aside, kicks him in the nuts and then shoots hi the forehead as he falls forward. Right looks around, confused; where’s Shotgun Steve gone? Right turns directly into Shotgun Steve FIRING THE SHOTGU OFF INTO HIS FACE FROM FOUR FEET AWAY, having ducked behi the front of a car. Right stumbles back, and blood pours from a dozen or so s holes in his face and neck; he also has a bunch of holes his upper chest and shoulders, which spot red with blood. looks stunned. Shotgun Steve, equally stunned, tries to cock the shotgun Mr. Right raises his pistol, holding it on Shotgun Steve.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pained) Drop that. Steve drops the shotgun. Mr. Right slightly lowers his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (genuinely baffled) Birdshot? They gave you birdshot? Shotgun Steve goes for his pistol, but Mr. Right immediat brings his gun up into Steve’s face.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t reach for your gun, that’d be a stupid way to die. Steve stares at him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (piercing shriek) FUCKING HURTS, homie! AAGGGHHH (immediately calm and friendly) That was, that was great. I totally didn’t see that coming. I’d be dead right now, you totally got me. Steve stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hate that feeling, what’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: SHOTGUN STEVE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Steve.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: I hate that feeling Steve, but there’s no denying it, man, you got me. Shotgun Steve. You are damn good. Why the fuck would they give you birdshot?

dialogues.speaker: SHOTGUN STEVE
dialogues.text: S..isamistake...Iunno... Mr. Right laughs, and shakes his head. Steve just stares him.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT
dialogues.text: (sighs) You should get out of here. Steve nods fervently.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Run, dude! Shotgun Steve takes off running. The friendliness seems t drain from Mr. Right’s face, and he looks alarmingly emotionally vacant, thinking. FLASH TO MR. RIGHT’S VIEW OF THE PARK EARLIER THAT DAY. Mr. Right sits on the bench with Charlie, and one by one, elements off the world crash away, finally leaving Charli and Mr. Right hanging in a void, and Martha sitting in Right’s car in the lot. Forty or so yards away stands Joh Howl. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Johnny Howl smiles and looks at Martha. Mr. Right looks horrified, and Charlie Cartigan drops away, dead. BACK TO RIGHT IN THE LOT.

dialogues.speaker: RIGHT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispers) Martha. INT. MARTHA’S APARTMENT BUILDING - HALLWAY Hopper stands outside of Martha’s apartment door, not mov The door creaks open, and Martha peers out. He looks at h

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Where’s the other guy?

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: Wally’s out in the car.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Is everything...

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: Everything’s fine.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: How long have you been following him?

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: Minch...three years. Wally came in later, after the change-over happened. (to Martha’s reaction) When he started killing his clients.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Oh. (long beat) Do you think I’m in danger?

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: You want the honest answer or the Federal answer?

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: Honest. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: I have no idea. We think he’s in danger; the man he killed has a lot of dangerous people backing him up. (beat, musing) Of course, so did the Picolos, and that didn’t help them.

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: The who?

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER
dialogues.text: A little syndicate up north; drugs, heroin mainly, thought they were really tough guys. Tried to hire Minch, bing bang boom, their guys are dead. They try to come after him for revenge, and the backlash destroys them. (holds up two fingers) One survivor. Of four leaders, and fifteen underlings, one guy lived. Everyone thought it was a rival gang, but-

dialogues.speaker: MARTHA
dialogues.text: You misunderstood, I meant...I meant am I in any danger from him?

dialogues.speaker: I...
dialogues.text: (beat) Minch has no friends. He barely ever talks to anyone. He spends hours in his apartment, sitting and not moving, staring at nothing, goes to work, sells cars, comes home. Around you, his behavior is...unique. He expresses himself; emotions other than that blank, happy thing he’s got going on. You’re the one person in my entire time tracking him that he’s had any kind of meaningful interaction with that didn’t end in a bullet...or a new car. Martha smiles a tiny bit, and Hopper, though he doesn’t smile, acknowledges it.

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe that doesn’t answer your question, but that’s all I’ve got. (beat) Personally, I’d say he hasn’t killed anybody that didn’t have it coming since the change-over. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOPPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So I think the real question is, do you believe that evil has an expiration date? Martha nods, and slowly closes the door. INT. RICHARD’S OFFICE - SHORTLY THEREAFTER Richard looks absolutely furious, yelling at Von and Shot Steve. Bruce stands by, watching, uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: And then he let you run away.

dialogues.speaker: SHOTGUN STEVE
dialogues.text: That idiot Howl gave me a shotgun with fucking birdshot-

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: Why didn’t you check the cartridge?

dialogues.speaker: SHOTGUN STEVE
dialogues.text: Why the fuck would I, why would you guys even have birdshot shotguns laying around!? Why the fuck would you only send three fucking guys-

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: Because we thought they’d be competent enough to kill one jack off by surprise, clearly, our mistake. (to Richard) This is bad, Richie, now he knows we’re gunning for him. I think we’ve just gotta lock it down, stay where we are, and-

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: And wait for him to come here and kill us? No fuckin’ thank you, Von. Where's Howl?

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: He’s-

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter. Get him, get him and fifteen guys and go pick up the girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: What? Fifteen guys?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Not including yourself and Howl, yeah. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: What? Why should I-

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Don’t you fuckin’ test me, Clevon.

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: Well what if he doesn’t come for the girl-

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I swear to god, don’t test me. Von laughs and shakes his head, and Richard stands immediately, coming around the desk; Von suddenly looks afraid.

dialogues.speaker: VON
dialogues.text: Richie, wait, Richie- Richard slaps Von across the face, nearly knocking him do

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Our uncle is dead. Two of our guys are dead. It is your fucking fault, you piece of shit worm cocksucker, and I have defended your worthless cokehead ass for years, FOR FUCKING YEARS, and now I realize, in full and vivid color, that it was a mistake.
